awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Effect of Iconicity on Phonetic and Phonological Processes in American Sign Language
awd_abstract_narration:
This dissertation research project examines a difference in the structure of spoken and signed languages. Although they are gestural/visual rather than auditory, signed languages, such as American Sign Language (ASL), are full languages with equal expressive complexity. This has only been recently recognized, however, so ASL research is in its infancy. Comparing signed and spoken languages can reveal the basic cognitive principles that underlie human language. The present study focuses on iconicity, which means that a word or sign resembles its meaning. For example, the sounds in the English word 'pop' mimic a popping noise, and the arrangement of the arm and fingers in the ASL sign 'tree' resemble a tree trunk and branches. Most spoken words are not iconic, but iconic signs are the norm rather than the exception in ASL. This study asks whether iconicity impacts the grammatical patterns of ASL. Do iconic and non-iconic signs function differently? Answering this question will help us better understand how the physical form of a language (speech or sign) impacts its mental organization.

To answer this question, grammatical patterns that occur in natural, everyday signing are compared in how they apply to iconic and non-iconic signs. Deaf adult participants are video recorded responding to open-ended prompts about Deaf cultural events. They then watch video clips of ASL signs and sentences in which specific grammatical patterns apply to iconic and non-iconic signs. They respond to each clip, indicating whether the ASL they saw is grammatically correct. If participants apply grammatical patterns differently to iconic versus non-iconic signs, this is evidence that iconicity is part of the grammatical structure of ASL, not just of individual signs, suggesting a fundamental difference from the structure of spoken languages. But if grammatical patterns apply in the same way to iconic and non-iconic signs, this suggests that even though individual signs are more iconic than spoken language words, this property does not impact the language’s grammatical structure. These findings will deepen our understanding of human language beyond what we can learn through spoken language research alone. This knowledge can inform a wide range of applications, such as language acquisition for Deaf babies and training for ASL interpreters. The video narratives collected in the study will be made publicly available and can also serve research in language teaching, interpretation, and Deaf cultural studies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Amelia Becker has completed her dissertation entitled "The Effect of Iconicity on Phonetic and Phonological Processes in American Sign Language," supported by an NSF Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant. This dissertation addressed a gap in the linguistics literature regarding iconicity, the property in which words or signs resemble their meanings. While it is well-known that many signs in American Sign Language (ASL) resemble their meanings, this dissertation is one of the first studies to ask if or how this resemblance affects how signers apply normal processes of variation to signs in real time. This was done through two studies.

In the first study, Deaf ASL signers provided judgments of two-handed ASL signs. These signs were shown both in their formal, two-handed form and in one-handed form, exhibiting a common process that can apply to two-handed signs called "weak hand drop." The results showed that, even when signs had very similar forms to one another, if one was very iconic and the other was not, participants rated the one-handed form of the more iconic signs as more natural than the one-handed form of the less iconic sign. This finding suggests that iconicity provides a secondary way for perceivers to access the meaning of a sign, and they may rely on this secondary option when a sign appears different from its usual form. 

For the second study, Deaf ASL signers were filmed providing responses to open-ended questions relating to Deaf culture and experience. These responses were annotated and the signs were coded for their location on and contact with the body. They were also coded for iconicity. Signs were then coded for whether they were produced in their usual, formal location or whether they had undergone the natural process of location change or hand-body contact loss. The analysis found that signs were no more or less likely to undergo these changes depending on their iconicity, even though these changes could mean losing the sign's resemblance to its meaning. Thus, while signers relied on remaining iconicity when perceiving one-handed versions of two-handed signs, iconicity did not affect the variation in location and contact they applied to their own signing.

The outcomes of this project are threefold. First, the findings contribute to our understanding of how and when iconicity shapes sign perception and production. The difference between the results of the two studies teach us that exactly how a specific linguistic processes interacts with iconicity can affect what results we should expect. Second, the videos collected for the second study and their annotations will be shared publicly online in order to add to high quality, machine-readable, open-source ASL data, which is currently lacking. And finally, in addition to compensating participants and purchasing filming equipment, grant funds were used to hire and mentor two ASL-signing masters student research assistants who conducted data annotation. Two Deaf ASL signing language consultants were also hired to collaborate in stimuli creation and production as well as translation and production of video-recorded instructions and IRB forms in ASL.
